Since I moved to the Mission four months ago I have made it my personal goal to try every taqueria in my neighborhood of 24th avenue. The rest of the goal? Not gaining mass LB's in the process. I'm most of the way through it, but two weeks ago Torta Gorda shot their way to the top of my  list by offering the best damn salsa in the city. And it's hot. Like, really, really hot. And you know that onion-y, habanero-y cabbage-y thing you can get at some taquerias? The coveted salsa with no name? Yeah, the one at Torda Gorda blows them all away. In every sense of the word. In fact, if you're not used to spicy this will be a bit too much for you, but I chose to pile it high on top of my chilaquiles and pay the consequences later. It was sooooo worth it. 

Which reminds me: Get the chilaquiles with eggs the way you like them and carna asada. I asked for over medium and was rewarded with the best eggs I've had in 34 years on this planet. It's like, how can you make an egg better? It's an 'effing egg. But they do. Their eggs taste betterr. 

That should be their motto: La Torta Gorda -- Our Eggs Taste Better. 

And did I mention they have a patio? Mmmhmm. It's there. Since they don't offer booze, and since I live right around the corner, I'm thinking I'll order of of their amazing juices and add my own dash of something adult-like. I'm thinking Cazadores. In fact, I'm thinking it's gonna be an awesome Cazadores-type of a summer on the patio of Torta Gorda gorging myself on chilaquiles and habanero salsa. 

Meet me there. I'll be the girl making sweet, sweet love to her food in the corner. It'll be pretty weird. You can't miss me.
author: Mel H.

description: Delicious tacos, cheap and fresh. Service was lovely and friendly.  Wish I lived nearby so I could go all the time!
author: Melissa S.

description:
One of the few places I found that has huitlacoche (a.k.a. Mexican truffles, a.k.a. corn smut...heehee!) quesadillas.

And they are AMAZING.

Sure, the huitlacoche may not be "fresh," but is there any real way of acquiring a stash of corn with a fungal infection? I doubt it. It's probably canned, but I DON'T CARE.

The flour tortilla appears to be made there, or at least hand-made SOMEwhere, and it's important to have a good tortilla surrounding a quesadilla.

Inky black liquid starts flowing from this thing, too. Don't wear white gloves while eating it.

Three cheers for this highly underrated delicacy!! :D
author: Cody K.

description:
The torta tinga (junior size) was incredibly delicious and filling.  I am totally going to get another torta here. The enchiladas verdes (chicken) were also tasty.  The refried beans were OK (maybe slightly too soupy for my taste), but the rice was delicious!

Service was prompt and friendly. Went for takeout; I'm sure I'll be going there again!!
author: R B.

description: Authentic and good. Ordered delivery at work for lunch. Came fast and hot. The carne Asada platter comes with steak rice beans nopales fried green onions and the best roasted pepper sauce on the side. Had enough for lunch and dinner later. Not sure how they make the rice but I'm now a fan of whatever style it was cooked. So good. Ordered a side of guacamole as well it was very fresh and huge. Everything was seasoned perfectly and carne cooked well. I will definitely order from here again
author: Lilia D.

description:
Not as divey and hole in the wall-ish as Tortas LP down the street. I think that's why the torta didn't taste as good. Or maybe just because it wasn't as flavorful and the toppings were somewhat lacking. 

Ordered up a tinga torta, which is shredded chicken cooked with onions, tomatoes, and chipotle. Wouldn't order it again because the tinga was really wet and made my torta super soggy. Plus, it didn't have that kick I was looking for with the chipotle. Tinga tu madre. Just kidding, these workers are cool. So they said they had avocados in the torta. Really? Didn't notice. 

They also have those bacon wrapped hot dogs here ($4). Way to early to order one of those for lunch tho. Those only taste good at 2am. 

Great place to go with coworkers.
author: Earl G.

description: In the heart of the Mission district with a bunch of coworkers, we stormed this medium sized establishment wanting large tortas to fill our stomachs.  All of us were ravenous coming in and most were in food comas coming out.  To say the tortas here are huge is an understatement.  These are enormous!  There's a wide range of tortas anod other items but I eventually setteld for the china poblano which is a torta that is equipped with carne asada, cactus, refried beans, and the usual condiments of sour cream, and avocado.  Also, there's a side of sauce that adds to the dynamics.  If you're brave, you can add your own hot sauce to add a slight kick to it.  If you come here with an empty stomach, you are guaranteed to go home in a wheelchair or wheel barrow (depending how you roll) since you'll be sleepy from all that food.
author: Ronald L.

description: I love this place! They have amazing tortas, juices, quesadillas and mexican hot chocolate!! I will be coming back soon!
author: Adriana H.

description: YUM!  I am not an expert on Tortas nor do I care if things are authentic.  I just care that what I am eating is good!!  This place delivered.  I have the vegetarian torta and it wsa delicious.  I had the junior and it was huge.  I cannot imagine eating the regular size!  Great price, nice service and oh the three types of hot sauce?!?!?  Fantastic!
author: Jane K.

description:
After getting hooked up with my new board at Mission Skateboards, I wandered down 24th St for a bite to eat. I remember reading about La Torta Gorda on Yelp and decided to seek it out. Luckily, I'm a visual learner and remembered what La Torta looked like based on the signage since I had no clue what the cross street was.

I was the second or third person in the restaurant and was served promptly. I ordered a mango agua fresca and a large torta with carnitas. This thing was pretty huge but served on a flat round roll which I never had before. The torta was good but the flavors didn't really pop as I would've expected. The agua fresca was excellent though.

Overall, more like 3.5 stars. Great service and a pretty decent torta.
author: Art O.

description: On 24th and the mission...how to chose which place to eat.  Well we happened to walk into La Torta Gorda.  A short line, (good sign), Friendly cook(good sign), great prices(good sign).  I ordered the Vampiro juice.  10 juices in one and a Carne asada torta....with Avocado and an Egg.  The counter person asked me to sample their homemade green enchilada's -omg(another good sign).  Then the torta came.  Was not soggy, was wrapped perfectly and wow did it taste perfect.  5 stars in every way.   If you still have room, the place across the street has Pies.  Never been but plan to try it also.
author: Dimitri M.

description:
had the chorizo & egg torta.  wasn't bad but wasn't great.  the chorizo & egg kinda clumped up versus being spread out evenly, and the flavor wasn't memorable.

maybe i just don't like tortas
author: Jeffry C.

description: Pierna enchilada torta - wow. Had a few bites of the boy's and wish I had my own. Will definitely be walking over there and getting one for myself.
author: Melody T.

description:
after walking around mission district, admiring all the murals, my friends and i started to get hungry. one of my friends, who is a SF native and recently moved back home after living on the east coast for the past few years, had said something like "i think i remember this place having a really good mole". it looks like a random hole in the wall and im really not sure if it really was the place she was thinking about, or if we had just stumbled upon another hidden gem.

its a small homey restaurant with counter seating and a few tables. the owner and other workers were very friendly, and even offered to take a group pic of us, without us even asking or hinting. 

i ordered the carne asada torta. it came on what looked like a whole wheat bun (!) with refried beans, avocado, queso fresco, onions, mayo and jalapenos or chipotle. i got the junior size which was a pretty good size torta. i wonder how big the regular size is then.

my friend ordered the mega cubana (milanesa, sausage, pierna, ham, chorizo, fried egg, turkey, queso fresco and american cheese). we called it a man sandwich. hahaah it looked pretty much like a cholesterol packed torta. he said it was good but it looked like there was a hot dog in it too. i think if you have a weak heart, you shouldnt get this. ahha

my other friend ordered the chile relleno and the taco placero (with your choice of meat, queso fresco, avocado and nopales). i forgot what kind she got but the owner offered to put two different kinds split on the taco since it was so big. in the menu it says its an XXL taco. its basically a really huge taco on a homemade tortilla. my friend is vegetarian so he made her a meatless taco. im not sure what was in it but it looked really good. the chile relleno was a red sauce kind. it was lightly battered and cheesy in the inside. you could taste the cheese and the chile. it was really good. not heavy at all.

my other friend got two tacos, i think the chicken and carnitas. they were small tacos, so i think two or three would be a good amount to get. 

my friends ordered mexican hot chocolate, which tasted like rich chocolate with a little cinnamon in it. i ordered a strawberry agua fresca. it was so good! it was like eating a fresh juicy strawberry. 

the owner said that his restaurant was featured in 3 different SF magazines and even had a "people on yelp love us!" sticker in the window :) he was super nice and even offered to let us pay our bill separately. my friend that lives in SF says that the mexican food in SF is nothing like what we have in LA, but this place was pretty good. i'd definitely recommend this place, just make sure you get there before they close. they close at 4PM on saturdays and sundays!

i left a gordita
author: Lina O.

description:
La Torta Gorda brought tears to my eyes today. The food is absolutely delicious and prepared with love, made apparent by the delicate flavors in the dishes and the pride and joy the staff displays. Today was my first visit, inspired by an article written about LTG my friend had passed on. She and I are constantly on the search for good Mexican food in the bay area - this place certainly delivers.

*Tortas are not the only thing on the menu. Other items were featured in the article I had read, so I went with those (below):

1) Quezadillas con Huitlacoche (mushroom that grows on corn, subtle-sweet-earthy flavor)
---This is not a quesadilla at all in the usual way. A handmade corn tortilla, filled with fresh corn, fresh epazote, huitlacoche, and a LITTLE bit of cheese is filling yet light, and very tasty. 

2) Tlacoyos al Albanil
---This handmade refried-black beans filled corn tortilla, topped with a light tomato sauce, fried egg, and sliced avocado, was my favorite of both dishes.

Accompanying my meal were three hot sauces from three different types of chiles, roasted - two red & a green. Those were lovely.

I complimented my server (perhaps also an owner) on the unusual and yummy dishes and he seemed to take pride, very graciously. He explained that the kitchen of La Torta Gorda was a unique one in The Mission; dishes prepared at LTG are traditional to central/southern Mexico, or Puebla.

As I was settling up, a woman who also worked there was waiting for her own lunch to arrive. She pointed to a picture of a dish near the "specials" board, called" CHILES EN NOGADA": a pork, peach & pear-stuffed chile, smothered in a light walnut  crema sauce, garnished with pomegranate seeds and fresh parsley. When it arrived, she insisted that I take a bite and try it. In a word: Ambrosia. Again, obviously prepared from the heart!

Another selling point to this place - the atmosphere: It is spotlessly clean and lovingly maintained, including the bathroom - a rarity in the business! Also, the old diner feel gives this place a genuine charm, complete with antique looking lights and wall sconces.

Finally, the service was FANTASTIC.

Go to La Torta Gorda and perhaps try something other than a torta. And go before they remove the "Chiles en Nogada" from their seasonal offerings.
author: Angela M.

description: The breakfast plates here are amazing.  Probably the coolest hidden outdoor patio on 24th.  Great Tortas!
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Came here for 7x7. They featured La Torta Gorda's Enchilada Torta.

I hate to say it,  but it wasn't all that for me. I read some of the reviews below and I'm kicking myself for not trying anything else, but I figured I love Mexican food already, this should be pretty delicious. So sad, I was wrong.
author: Rosie W.

description: We are so happy to live by this local gem, have been huge fans ever since they opened back when they were just a walk-up torta window! Now that they have a full restaurant we can happily have breakfast lunch and dinner there. Love the torta but the plates are really delicious and authentic.
author: DeAnna G.

description: Stopped in here based off Yelp reviews, and we weren't disappointed. We had a late lunch, consisting of tacos and quesadillas. The tacos were similar to your average street taco, but with way more meat. The quesadilla was good and cheesy, just like a quesadilla should be. Overall, pretty good.
author: Kevin M.

description: It is the only Torta place I know so far in Bay area.  The service was friendly and they even give taste of drink for my friends who want to find out what was Te de Jamaica. I got Torta de Pierna Enchilada the meat was very tender and the sauce gave more moisture to the meat.  The bread was quite fresh.  However, I could not taste much of the beans, maybe I use to red beans and they use pinto beans.  The queso fresco was so little no taste about it.  The small size (junior I think) only get you satisfied, if you are hungry get the large one.  The food is poblano, I am not so sure of the differences yet.  I need to keep eating different type of mexican food.  I will put an extra star if I find better food in there.
author: Z G.

description: horrible service, took 45 min to get our food. Waste of my time. I would never come back here again. Almost got a ticket bc I waited so long for the food. Waiters don't even come by and check in with us after waiting 30+ min
author: Sophie L.

description:
Carne asada platter with beans, rice, and nopales. All were pretty run of the mill, except the cactus. Granted it does have a slimey nature to it, I still have had better at several places. The asada torta that we ordered was very bland, and also lacking in the lettuce, tomato, salsa. Did they forget? But since they are known for the tortas, I'll try another one next time before I activate the shun.

(Free delivery in the area. Wonder if they can do inside SFGH..)
author: Ray C.

description:
The chiles en nogada served here are excellent.

 It is a traditional dish from Puebla and consists of a poblano chile stuffed with shredded meats, aromatics, fruit, and spices covered with a walnut cream sauce and pomegranate seeds.  It comes with a large roll of fresh bread  to soak up the sauce.  It is available only during the pomegranate season, October - March?  

They do a great job preparing this dish.  The service is great and everyone is very friendly.
author: Lloyd R.

description:
VIVA LA TORTA!!!!!!!!!!!

* dangerously affordable
* fast & friendly service
* DELICIOUS
* clean, kitchy, randomly awesome interior decor
* the "junior" size is plenty of food to fill you up & the "large" will induce sudden and instantaneous food-coma. (yes, while you're still seated, with food in your mouth).

fyi: watch out for the random open/closed hours - but shift your life accordingly to make the trip happen.

no doubt: best torta in sf!
author: Anjali V.

description:
BEST TORTAS IN TOWN. best quality ingredients, incredible bread, amazing carnitas, and mango smoothie - fresh, whole mango smoothie for 3 bucks? and watermelon aguas frescas (which tastes like smooshed watermelon but without any sugar added... 16 oz for 3 bucks? unheard of... watermelon is expensive). Um... what else - clean restaurant, great breakfast... amazing sauces, great quality of QUESO FRESCO, my favorite cheese, oh and, I don't know, the food speaks for itself. And the left overs keep well, too. Just turn the oven onto 400 degrees and cook for 10-15 in the paper. Don't bother with the tortas at El Farolito (even though it's amazing) or Cancun (even though it's fantastic). Don't bother. Walk the few extra blocks to La Torta Gorda and have your meal here.

Oh, and thumbs up to the awesome staff. Truly a great mom-and-pop shop.
author: Y K.

description:
OMG this place is amazing! 
i loved it!
food was great and so was the service=] the people here are very friendly and joke a lot  very very good deff will be going back=]
author: Mayra R.

description:
I was craving some authentic Mexican food and this place claims to have it. I have had more flavorful tacos from a taco cart on the street than this place.

This place is a little runed down and looks like it's had better days.
 
We ordered the Jr. Steak torta, a regular carnitas taco and Taco Placero Al Pastor. The Steak Torta had no flavor, the carnitas taco was moist yet also lacking in taste, now the Placero Al Pastor taco was a little better but the nopales tasted like the came out of a jar.

With all that being said, the only reason I would stop back into this place would be if it's raining and I needed to get out of the rain.
author: Raw W.

description:
So I am pretty insistent on getting my 7X7 List 100 Things to Eat list done and in my belly. So out to the Mish we went for lunch today with my trusty sidekick Loren. 

This place was awesome, the pierna enchilada torta was tasty and even the junior size filled my belly and made me very happy. Tasty panini like bread (nice and crispy), juicy tender pulled pork, jalapenos for crunch, pickled onions and a spicy smoky flavored salsa to top it off. The owner was very friendly and suggested some other unique options they specialize for us to try our next trip around. They specialize in really fresh, homemade corn tortillas and different dishes surrounding these. Will DEFINITELY be back... we got lucky and had a sunny day in which we were able to sit on the patio and enjoy our meal with some Mexican coke.

PS- If you are hitting the list as well, Dynamo Donuts is across the street and Humphrey Slocombe ice cream is about 2 blocks down. We hit 3 spots in one hour... woohoo!
author: Sarah A.

description: We like the food here a lot, particularly the huitlacoche and flor de calabaza stuff that we've fallen in love with in Mexico and transports us back there each time.  But I really have to call out props for the service.  We've been to various fancy-pants restaurants lately where the so-called servers hadn't bothered to learn what they needed to and couldn't care less if their attitude interfered with our experience.  Meanwhile, the lady who waited on us at Torta Gorda was so attentive and so thoughtful ... without being intrusive ... that she could really teach all of those "professional" waitpeople how to do their jobs.  She really made the experience even more positive for us.
author: pablo p.

description:
Five stars for the pierna enchilada sandwich which was amazing!
I loved the combination of the toppings on a toasted bread...pulled pork, avocado...mmmmmm...
 The portion was huge (i shared the sandwich with my mom) and the price low.
author: Ula F.

description:
So I'll start off w/ the best to the not-so-best in comments:

(1) Service: GREAT... funny, very friendly and welcoming staff.  We strolled in at 7:55pm; didn't realize they closed at 8pm.  They still let us in and didn't insist on us ordering just take-out.  Sweet!

(2) Location: Good... especially since I love the Mission.  24th has been revamped so much.  You have the local taquerias in the area, but now are mixed in w/ a whole bunch of cute trendy restaurants.  El Torta Gorda isn't one of those "trendy" spots, but they are definitely a friendly bunch.

(3) Food: Okay... honestly what brought me in was the 7x7 list, so we had to try the Pierna Enchilada Torta.  It was good, and big enough to split between 2 people.  The seasoned pork came in a Panini-style type of flat bread and there were chunks of crunchy jalapenos hiding in there.  Hot!  They served some kind of hot BBQ sauce w/ it; very flavorful.  What I really, really liked was their tacos, Al Pastor and Carne Asada.  We requested their corn tortillas... yummy!  The tacos were a good size, filled w/ lots of chunky meat, onions, and cilantro.  I was surprised they didn't serve Chips and Salsa to go w/ their dishes.  Weird, I thought that was the norm! 

(4) Drinks: Non-alcoholic.  I was craving a beer for some reason, but they didn't offer alcoholic beverages!    The waiter was funny though and offered to grab one down the street and bring it back for me. LOL, see what I said about friendly staff??!! 

Bottom-line, it was good.  I probably won't make it one of my "regular" spots, but will come back to try their Chilaquiles for breakfast.
author: Joy A.

description:
Not half bad.  Yummy little sandiwches.  Could be larger and cheaper, but still, not half bad.  they open pretty early also which is nice when you want a veggie Torta for breakfast.  

The Tortas are not as good as El Farolito down the street, but they are very interesting taste-wise.  i like them, but not the best, but still yummy.

They delivers if you order over $15.  to the Mission, Noe Valley and Bernal Heights.  (415) 724 - 5399
author: Cynthia B.

description:
You are likely to walk past LTG without it even occurring to you that its totally worth checking out. I personally think, LTG is one of the few well kept Mission secrets. I like LTG for the following reasons:
1. its a clean restaurant
2. the service is good
3. the prices are reasonable
4. there isn't usually a wait
5. and there is backyard seating
author: Vivek N.

description:
Time to change the name of this place to "Bandwagon" in honor of all of us about to jump all over it.

Feeling indecisive-slash-stark-raving-starving, so I and my manly partner decided to follow the advice of the SF Weekly reviewer and got the pambazo torta (chorizo, potato, crema, lettuce, jalapeno on a roll) and the chicken mole. We also took the waitress' advice and got the guava-banana agua fresca. She even gave us a taste to help us make up our minds - sweet service.

Bliss! The pambazo is the best breakfast sandwich alternative to the classic egg-cheese-bacon. (Our table's appalling-slash-brilliant suggestion of the morn': add bacon to the pambazo for all-out indulgence). Schmear that with some of the roasted red hot sauce in the squeeze bottle and nothing can get you down. 

The mole was all subtle flavor-layering (a little salt perked it up), and the chicken was bone-abandoning-tender. The refried beans...well, they sucked in a watery, forgettable, flavorless way, but they were a small loss in a plate of all else perfection.

Caution: the red chili sauce in which they soak the pambazo roll may stain your mouth like you've been making out with a cheap whore all morning. 

And, can I give a shout out for the decor? Abandoned diner meets items that didn't sell at the garage sale. Boomerang-patterned 50s tables and hot red chairs, some wicked campy candelabra-topped pillars....I wanted to curl up at a table with the Sunday paper and never leave.
author: Lauren G.

description:
Stopped in because the Street Food Fest was a fuckin mess. Seriously. 50+ person lines for every booth. Wanted to chop my thumb off. 

Anyways.... I got the jr.-sized carnitas torta. It was tasty. The other guys I was with ordered chorizo. They seemed to enjoy. Think I paid less than $10, including a drink. I'll go back...at the very least, to thank them for saving my thumb.
author: Aaron Z.

description: Delicious all the way around! Freshly made licuados and squeezed orange juice. Breakfast menu is limited but good. For lunch try the enchiladas or tacos. Recommend sitting at the bar and watching the cooks make all the deliciousness.
author: John S.

description:
*** PATIO SEATING!!! ***

Reasonable prices. Yummy, spicy Mexican food.

I had a 'Large' Torta de Carnitas for $7.95. If I knew how bid the portions are I would have ordered the 'Reg' for $5.95. Most amazing. Great Carnitas!

Even if it's too cold to sit outside the inside part is like an old ice cream parlor.

I'll be back.
author: BigJohnS F.

description:
Man, this is one of the best Tortas I've had, ever. I've passed this place a hundred times and finally decided to try it. The carnitas was tender and not too greasy, the blend of ingredients was portioned just right and the bread was truly amazing - crispy on the ouside yet tender and moist on the inside, not chewy or tough at all. The topper was the homemade chipotle sauce. 
This sandwich was so good I went back the next day. For people with normal sized stomaches, I recommend the "junior" size. The "regular" is enough to feed 2.

Nom nom nom...
author: Dave F.

description: Was in the neighborhood so decided to try this place out. Small nothing fancy. It was empty around 2pm on a Sunday. decided to try the famous Pierna Enchilada Torta . It was good--not a ton on it, I saw  bit of avocado and the meat but it could have used a bit more sauce as the bread was quite large. It was good but nothing I would write home about. A junior is about the size of in-n-our burger so it would be have been good with a side to share but I didnt see any on the menu.
author: Nicole S.

description:
came for the pierna (pulled pork) torta
came out like a panini.  bread is soft and all the ingredients are soft, thus could use a different textural element.  check out nearby los picudos.
author: Rob C.

description:
Breakfast here was vile. The refried beans were more like pinto beans mashed up and put in lukewarm water. The huevos con chorizo had small pieces of what looked like chorizo but had no taste. My friend ordered sopes and got tostadas. And, it was all really pricey! Highly disappointing.

Most likely I should've gotten a totra, eh?
author: Dina G.

description:
Went here last night and had the enchiladas rojas con pollo and it was perfect. That's right, perfect. Four lovely rolled enchiladas filled with shredded (though not at all dry) chicken and topped with a slightly spicy red sauce, crema, and healthy slices of avocado. They come with refried beans, a sprinkling of cheese, and rice...all for about 8$.
My friend had the mole which was also bursting with flavor. It's refreshing to find fresh straightforward food for a great price.
author: Clara I.

description:
You've found a true fan. BTW it's me. Every time I come to LTG I wait at least a good 10 minutes for my torta. I consider that a good sign. 
Been coming here for about 6 months now (10 visits) and I've never been disappointed. In fact, I've had life changing moments here. That's how much we trust this place. You should too.
author: Mike M.

description: So glad I stopped in here!  Amazingly good, legit tortas.  I ordered the grilled chicken which was fantastic (w queso fresco and jalepenos).  Simple, no nonsense grub.   OJ freshly squeezed filled with pulpy goodness.  Will def be hitting this place up for future meals!
author: Heather F.

description:
I frequented this place a lot more when I lived around the corner, but even now that I've moved and have lots of torta places around, I still sometimes make the special trip to get one of their carnitas tortas. Yum!! I hear that their tacos and other offerings are also yummy, but honestly I can never bring myself to stray from the torta menu. They even have some frou-frou veggie sandwiches, though I mostly come here when I'm craving meat. 

Also, the service is awesome, unassuming and friendly. They also let the school I work at have fundraisers where a percentage of food purchased go to our school- gotta love an establishment that gives back to the community!
author: Nicole A.

description:
this place serves a 5 star torta.  we were at SFGH yesterday for work so we walked down the street to La Torta Gorda per the recommendation of an SFGH employee.  Smart move on our part to listen. 

We were seated out on the back patio and had a delicious lunch.  Two of us opted for the regular sized carnitas torta.  We both only ate half and had the other half for dinner.  It was chock full of delicious carnitas, and the saucy flavors (including my fav: mayo) tied it all together.  If I worked near here I'd probably grab a junior torta on a regular basis for lunch.  Our other lunchmates went for a quezadilla and taco.  neither seemed to have any complaints, so i call it win-win.  Our misison mexican food craving was beyond satisfied with these giant sandwiches of deliciousness.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Came here for breakfast (at 1pm, hey don't judge...) on a Sunday. We sat on the cute patio in the back. The aguas frescas were delicious - watermelon and mango, mmm! The food and the three sauces on the table were also yummy - we had chilaquiles, huevos con mole, and some other dish that I don't remember the name of but involved huevos and queso and arroz. Huge portions and very flavorful. I'll definitely have to come back to try non-breakfast foods!

Our only gripe was that the food came out way before the drinks. We had to remind someone, and it still took awhile for them to appear.

By the way, put in your order at the counter, at least if you're sitting outside, not sure about inside, or else you'll just be awkwardly sitting and staring at each other while waiting for a waiter for a very long time.
author: Kim B.

description:
This is my favorite torta place in SF overall.  Their Puebla-style dishes (huitlacoche, squash flour, black mole) is all pretty good, mole in particular, but not really the specialty of the house (nor as economically priced), and neither is (I presume without having ever ordered it) the white-person breakfast stuff.  The specialty is the tortas, and these are really amazing tortas.  The bread is rad, the meat is cooked to order by attentive, professional cooks (who aren't surly if you ask them to do things in a specific way!).  There's a lot I haven't tried yet (tinga! chorizo!) because my "usual" (in the photos) is such a charmer I can never bring myself to experiment beyond it.

A note about drinks: tortas are traditionally accompanied by smoothies, and I think their shake-menu might be shrinking, but if you come in between rushes, they'll make fancy/custom/crazy drinks like "the jamaican hammer," which is banana+vanilla ice cream+double shot of espresso!!!
author: throw a.

description:
Just having moved to sf I've been looking forward to trying some of the missions famous Mexican treats. 

My coworkers took me here for lunch my first week and i was def happy with their choice! I had the jr carne asada torta and was certain I'd be back for more. In hind sight I'd probably get a regular next time. But that's the only thing I'd change for next time.
author: omid a.

description:
Can you picture a more quintessential 24th street scene? Spanish music playing. The guy who yells "GOAL" doing his thing on TV. Tortas being served. It was my sister's first time in this part of town, and I was hoping La Torta Gorda would deliver the goods. Indeed they did.

We both got the junior grilled chicken with refried beans, which we agreed was anything but junior. The guy taking our order was very accommodating, adhering to our requests to leave the bad stuff (cheese, mayo) off and put the good stuff (spinach, tomato) on. We also agreed it was absolutely delicious.

Splendid service, quintessential atmosphere, great prices, fantastic food. And an Obama picture on the door. The Mission at its finest!
author: Jason B.

description:
I love tortas! Walked to La Torta Gorda from Noe Valley to work up an appetite. Great service once we got here...homey feel to the restaurant. We ordered the Pierna Enchilada Torta (on the 7x7 list) and the Extra Large carne asada Taco. Oh man were both delicious!

Torta was full of stuff - beans, avocada, pork, jalapenos...so much more, but I can't remember! It was a massive torta! The taco was full of thick juicy and tender strips of carne asada, onions, bite size nuggets of cactus, and other stuff I can't remember :) They gave us 3 types of salsa to use as well. Oh man. Everything was devoured. I think I used 4 pieces of napkin. Eating tortas gracefully is quite difficult to do!

I'd come back here and try the other tortas. And the tacos. Everything tasted so fresh. Yummy!
author: Carol L.

description: Love this place. Really Good guacamole and pico de Gallo. Try the Jamaican hammer smoothie.
author: James L.

description: Came here because of the good reviews - but was disappointed with the food.  I ordered huevos rancheros and expected a more authentic dish but instead was greeted with a plate full of flavorless tomato sauce with two eggs and some random fried rice.  My husband got the Milanesa de res torta which only came with extras of beans, cheese and some jalapeño with bread so dense it soaked up any flavor.  It's hard trying new places and is really a let down when it doesn't work out.  Nice layout though and service was good - but not for us :/
author: Carissa S.

description: Their vegetarian torta is one of the best deals in town. Eat half on the outdoor patio, take half to go, and tip well!
author: Mel M.

description:
Good:

Nice patio in the back. Table service.  Lots of menu options.  Awesome bread.  I mean, really awesome.  Excellent flavor in my torta. 
 
Bad:

The al pastor was grizzly and tough.  Good flavor, bad texture.

I didn't measure precisely, but it seemed like a 20-minute wait for my torta.  The restaurant had fewer than 10 customers in it at the time.
author: Brett N.

description: Their Cuban torta lasted me through two meals and every bite was glorious! The staff was very friendly and attentive and I felt comfortable in this homey feeling spot. I would reccomend this to any sandwich lover.
author: Jon D.

description:
This place is phenominal.  the sandwiches are good and big as hell.  
You ever eat something when your really stoned or drunk and think it's the best thing ever?
 well I wasn't either one and that's how I felt after eating one of these.
author: christopher h.

description: Best place to eat in the mission great breakfast and the tortas look delicious!!!! This will definitely be a repeat place to eat at
author: Teresita M.

description:
Ordered a vegetarian torta, and wow, these things suck.

It was like a meatless sandwich,wtf?!

I ordered the Jr size which on the menu said $6.35 and the lady charged $7.30.  I figured whatever and waited for my order.  I got what looked like a little square panini with lettuce, tomato, jalepeno, mayo, avocado and that's it.  Th

It wasn't a vegetarian torta, it was a $7.30 meatless torta.  And the worst part was that they couldn't even fill the little sauce container halfway with sauce.  The cashier wasn't very warm either.

What a waste.
author: Jorge R.

description: Best sit down Mexican restaurant in SF. Puebla-focused, but has all kinds of things. Particularly love going for breakfast. One of my faves.
author: F G.

description:
While I've never been to an actual diner in Mexico, I get the sense that this is what one feels like.

The pork tortas was absolutely delicious, as was my friend's soup. Service was friendly. When we noticed someone ordering an off-menu plantain item, we requested it too, and they made it for us.

Still would like to try out other tortas places along 24th street first though.
author: Mark A.

description:
Order whatever they tell you to- seriously, they listen to what you want and then give you something better, off the menu and seasonal. For me, it was quesadillas, one with squash blossoms and another one with corn and mushroom. To die for! 

My friends had the chicken mole enchilada, veggie tacos and a carne asada torta. Everyone was over the moon with their order. 

We also brought in our own beer (leave it in the brown bag) and shared a strawberry auga fresca that was sweet and refreshing. 

Great outdoor patio seating, super nice staff. They got four stars because two out of six orders came out wrong (but were quickly replaced) and the food took forever to come out (they were packed to the gills and took 40-minutes plus to deliver our food to the table).
author: Rena B.

description: This little sandwich place is truly a hidden gem in the mission. My friend Tammy 'Tamara' introduced me to to their Torta sandwiches back when, and I've been fiending ever since. The hours are a little funny, so I can usually only catch this place during the weekend, but it's worth it. Everything I've tried there so far  has been great: cheap prices, large portions, fresh meat, cheese, bread and all the rest - and the staff are so friendly and quick.  When I was waiting for my mozarrella sandwich this weekend I noticed alot of Mission regulars ordering the chicken parmigana and I've made a mental note to try it next - but honestly, I have a feeling that their whole menu is "on point."
author: Jessica T.

description:
SHARDS OF GLASS IN MY TORTA!! 

Look, I loved this place, but in the middle of my last torta, there was a big 'ole hunk of glass that I bit down on (thankfully, not too hard). I loved their food, but I'm sorry man, a time with glass in your food is one time too many. This type of crap should never happen.
author: Jesse L.

description:
DONT EAT HERE THEY SERVE DOG! Kidding. But their takeout menu does say they offer "Toasted Beagles." Note: please don't ever change that! I'm cheesy enough that it makes me giggle every time.

Tasty tortas, probably my favorite on 24th,the junior is definitely big enough for one. I've also had the grilled vegetable and goat cheese sandwich, very nice. Sometimes though you got to be assertive to get attention. The ordering location is ambiguous and when it gets busy folks just spread down the counter, looking lost and hungry.
author: Hallie R.

description: I am  a fan of the small inexpensive take out place in 24th in the Mission. I headed over there to  have breakfast the other day then realized they have a sit down restaurant next door. My friend and I had a good meal of grilled chicken chilequiles in a green sauce. It was one of the better versions I've had. The chicken was large chunks of white breast meat and overall it was not salty and not greasy.
author: E. M.

description:
My girlfriend and I have a Saturday morning ritual. We wake up, blisteringly hungover, having consumed the better part of a bottle of Jack Daniels the night before, our mouths feeling like the cat shit in them, heads pounding away like a porn star. We lie there quietly and start whispering "Torta" to one another. 

At some point one of us poor bastards actually has to get out of the bed and be the one to go downstairs and pick up our tortas. I'm not gonna lie to you--it's usually her because let's face it, she's whipped. 

She comes back with our chorizo, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich or our torta con al pastor and two fat Gatorades and we hunker down on the couch for another useless Saturday.

I'm gonna tell you right now, there are very few things in life that one of their tortas cannot cure. Cancer? Maybe. Tourette's? Quite possibly. A hangover large enough to stop a herd of oxen in their tracks? Fuck yeah.

As a bonus, all of the guys who work here are SO NICE. If you're dining in though, the music will make your eardrums bleed.
author: kdub ..

description:
This is one of my favorite spots so far in my new home.   I've always been a fan of the Torta, but this place is a whole other level.   

The first time I went in there it was during the lunch rush and it was quite busy.   It took 15 minutes or so to get my sammich, which is excessive, but again, it was busy so I just chilled up at the counter.   The lady who took my order was friendly despite being pretty overwhelmed with annoying customers....

On that note, let me just say that I hate white people.   I know, I know...I'm white...but believe me, I hate myself too.   If your new age hippy diet isn't in line with what's on the menu, go somewhere else.  Don't waste the staff's time with a barrage of questions about the ingredients and then expect them to build you a custom tie-dyed torta for you and your fellow Berkeley faculty members.  I'm a hater.  I know.

Back to the Gorda.    Fabulous.   My first sammy was a carne asada and i was a happy little clam.    One thing to note:  They offer both "Junior" and "Regular" size tortas.  Since I'm a wannabe, I order the regular and so far have not made it trhough more than 3/4 of a sandwich.  Apparently I'm not a boy, but not yet a man.   

My second trip I had to try the Cubano.  What a crazy sandwich that thing is...pork, turkey , hot dogs...you name it.   It was yummy and deadly all at the same time.   I foresee many trips to the Gorda in my future.   I think the next trip will involve a breakfast torta.    Should be good times....
author: Scott W.

description:
I'm always torn on the weekends--do I continue to walk smugly by the wad of hipsters milling about outside the (lovely, but not-so-weekend-friendly) St. Francis, or do I pause to tell them they are missing out on a quick, delicious meal that will leave more change in their pockets?

Someday I suppose I'll try to clue them in, but until then, you yelpsters can enjoy the roomy environs in peace. The tortas are huge and are the best I've had here in the city: 
the bread: grilled to perfection
the meat (my fave is Al Pastor): yumsville
other stuff: a nice schmear of refried beans, mayo, onions, queso, jalepenos 

It adds up to sandwich perfection. 

Their breakfast sandwiches are equally delicious -- they scramble your choice of meat (bacon, chorizo, ham)  with some eggs and cheese and serve it on yet another tasty bread product. I recommend adding avocado for a maximum flavor celebration.

They also do fresh juice and will whip up a great espresso drink. Throw in a very clean and classy environment and some Futbol on the TV and you've got yerself one nice meal--without the wait and all the "ohmigodsdidyouseehowdrunkjimmywaslastnight?!?!?!"
author: Chris O.

description:
This was my first torta experience, which is surprising seeing that I've been living in the deep Mission for 3 years now. I didn't find anything all that special with tortas but I did appreciate a Mexican cuisine that wasn't just some other arrangement of tortilla, meat, cheese, and salsa. I ordered a junior carnitas torta (definitely appreciate the junior size) and was pleased with the thick fresh bread and well-seasoned meat. 

La Torta Gorda gets 4 stars because they provide a quick, cheap, simple option for when you're hungry. Also, service was great - we got the royal treatment when they set up a table for us in the back patio. I'm completely satisfied with this torta joint and don't feel the need to try out any others in my hood.
author: Susan L.

description:
The chef/owner/server had to pause and make sure we really did want a plate of the mole poblano, 3 kinds of quesadilla, the carne asada huraches, AND the chile relleno.  For the three of us.
Um, yes.  And that was us practicing restraint.  
I'm just not much of a sandwich person, but if I were, I'm sure I'd be all over these l-o-a-d-e-d tortas.  Happily La Torta Gorda does way more...breakfasts, lunch/dinner platters of some of the most fantastic mexican food I've had.  
Mole is no joke....there's some 20 ingredients in that stuff? Easy to be too sweet, or too thick, or too flavorless.  La Torta Gorda's is right up there with the best with a rich color, and deeply layered tangy flavor.  This is like grandma's-secret-recipe good.  That, and the quesadillas were just stand-out amazing to me, though the other entrees we got were good, too.  The hand-made corn tortillas were thick, crusty and made everything stuffed into them that much better.
It just kinda sucks that they close so early!  I often don't get out of work before they close at 7? 8?  
Still - I'm jonesing to go back. There's still the chilaquiles to try....and the huevos divorciados....OOH the enchilades, the ENCHILADES....and the sopas....
author: CINDY K.

description: I had breakfast with a friend the other day here. The owner told us about the breakfast specials and... well, his passion for his dishes shows through brightly. And the meal was excellent! A great breakfast experience. Some of their waitstaff don't speak English but that's ok.
author: Lee S.

description:
I just tried the pancakes from here and theyre HUGE! I swear they must be genetically enhanced, maybe they poured some of that ooze on it that made the ninja turtles. the pancakes are real thick, they give you 3 of them for under 5 bucks...best cakes ive ever had. hopefully they dont go skimpy on them later or this just wasnt a mistake.

also tried the croussaint chorizo egg and cheese sandwich...  

i been getting the grilled chicken sandwich at least once or twice a week, served on a dutch crunch roll and i usually include some queso fresco to give it a bit more flavor. way healthier than a torta de milanesa and tastier too

5 stars to all this stuff...this is still my favorite spot for a quick breakfast or lunch
author: fern d.

description:
If you find yourself in the heart of the mission and need some lunch, this is a great place to pick up a sandwich. I have been here countless times and they're very consistent. I can't vouch for the tortas, though my coworker swears by them, but their sandwiches are totally fresh---they don't even slice the meat until you order. 

Be daring and order the "Julia special," (off-menu & my coworker's invention) chicken breast, cream cheese, chipotle peppers, pickles, and avocado--like I said, daring. They also have great veggie options, and one sandwich is big enough for 2 people to share...
author: Dora A.

description:
God Damn these are some big sandwiches!  Awesome flavor good service you really can't go wrong.  So if you want something other than a burrito this is a great spot.  Sit at the bar and take your time picking the right one off the huge list.

Going to have to try the Mole' and I'll report back.
author: Jason S.

description:
If you want to try something different this is the spot! Started my order with a liquado de mamay! This exotic fruit accentuates chocolate in the most complimentary way and a milkshake made with this is hard to
Find! Then I ordered the chiles en nogada.. Wow. Chili rellenos topped with pomogranet .. For the vefetarian order yourself a quesadilla made with pumpkin flowers. Service was great.
author: jorge d.

description:
My life sucks!  I have to work on many weekends (unlike like 99% of my coworkers), I don't have a car (not necessarily sucky, but when your in BFSSF, far from any cookery type place, some suckiness starts to set in) and there are not too many places i can pick up a lunch on my way to work on a Sunday morning (I guess thing could be worse).  La Torta Gorda is open at 6:30 AM on SUNDAY!!!  Not that I am even close to getting up by then, but it does mean that when I drag myself out of bed, i can get a fat torta on my way through the mission.  One mean sannie too, they not cheap, but when i get a regular size, they are two meals worth of food easily, so in the end they are a bargain.  

I've had the milanesa and the carnitas tortas so far, and both were quite good.  I found the milanesa tender and flavorful, while though the carnitas were good, they were a tad dry.  As you've probably read, each sandwich comes with refried beans, cheese, avocado, and jalepenos.  The bread might be a little thick, but it's soft and doesn't get too much in the way of enjoying the fillings.      

Oh man, i gotta try the Cubano, and the chorizo con huevos...
Oh man, i gotta try the horchata....
author: Adrian L.

description:
Tortas Los Picudos is much, much better.  Tortas El Primo is better.

Pros:

(1) The regular size sandwich is gigantic.

(2) The carnitas are pretty tasty, not fatty enough, but still good.

Cons:

(1) Milanesa de res is too thin.  This results in a breaded jerky sandwich.

(2) Refried beans on the torta.  I know this is a style, but it is not a good one.

(3) No veggies on the torta.  I forget this when I order, and I am surprised when my sandwich only has meat, cheese, beans, avocado, and jalepeno on it.  A little lettuce and tomato go a long way (and yes, tomato is a fruit, I know).

(4) The bread is huge, but something is not quite right.  I can't say for sure, but maybe it is a little dry / too crumbly / too thick so that it doesn't heat properly.

I feel like I've given this place a fair share of chances, and I always regret coming here instead of Tortas Los Picudos.  On my last visit here, I was the only guy in the joint, and TLP had a giant crowd waiting to order.

Honestly, I would give this place two stars, but the staff is very nice  This review is based only on the tortas, I have not tried any of their other food.
author: David C.

description:
Alright. I'll admit it. I was a sucker and paid for 7x7's June "Best of" issue. Nestled amongst the "best of"'s was La Torta Gorda. The bf is in love with tortas, and since I've never had one before, I decided this may be worth the trek out to the Mission. I kept this place filed away in the back of my brain for one of those days when we get tired of the restaurants around us in the Richmond District.

That day came last week and I draaaagged the bf and myself off our lazy butts and into my car, me driving and silently hoping that my pain-in-the-ass-ishness about going would be rewarded with a tasty dinner choice. 

We were rewarded. Oh lordy, were we rewarded.

The place was empty, which seemed strange because of all the praise 7x7 and Yelpers were heaping onto it. The bf and I placed our orders (torta carnitas for me, torta carne asada for the bf) and sat down. The food came up fast and while we were waiting, 3 or 4 people (regulars, it seemed) came and went, all ordering food to go.

We bit into those tortas and mmmm.. heavenly. The cheese was good, the bread was wonderful, the meat.. meaty deliciousness. It was definitely worth the trek and assuaged my worries that I'd. be. made. a. fool. (Nobody ever likes to be the person who drags someone else to the lame party, the whack bar, or.. the bad torta place?)

HA! IN YOUR FACE, THESE TORTAS WERE AWESOME AND WORTH THE TRIP!

Ahem. So, in summary. Go here. Eat the tortas. If you are uber-hungry, get the regular. Otherwise the junior is a good size to get.

Funny side note: you can buy (order?) cup of noodles here!

Oh, oh, oh! I almost forgot: the staff is awesome. They were really nice and even handed us different hot sauce when they noticed that we were using the El Tapatio (sp?) sauce. "Oh, here you go. This hot sauce is better." Sweeeet!
author: Dianne d.

description: Went there again with my dad and discovered this is place is better than i first expected, my dad ordered 2 carne asada tacos and said 'wow que chingon' and he's very hard to impress (my dad was born and raised in El Salvador) with Mexican cuisine but he loved it. Equally as impressive was the pina colada we ordered, made fresh on the spot, great compliment to the spicy food we were enjoying. A place you have to visit more that once to really appreciate the great variety and quality of their food. Big ups do yo thang LTG!
author: Julio S.

description: 3.5 stars for the al pastor torta which has marinated pork and pineapples! The pineapples and jalapenos were a good touch since they made the torta a lot juicier! The cubana had too much meat and was dry compared to the al pastor. Also, I don't think hot dog slices should be in my sandwich, so I wouldn't order the cubaba again. The tortas are huge, so share with friends if you don't have a big appetite. We split 2 among 4 people and I was stuffed!
author: Cindy L.

description: I had a really good Torta, way too much food for me to finish in one sitting. I need to come back for breakfast some time.
author: R O.

description:
Late for work and need a delish sando to get you through until noon? 
This is the spot. Fast service and quality. 

Torta de pavo sin mayonessa.
author: Joe G.

description:
I don't give very many 5 star reviews but really this place is awesome.

The staff are friendly, it has that wonderful unassuming, homey, family  diner feel (which I love), and they serve basic, filling, working-class, Mexican food.   If the small town where I grew up in North Carolina were in Mexico instead, I'd be 100% at home instead of just 90% :)

The portions are huge, and they take time to prepare the food right.   Everything I have had so far is delicious and fresh, and I've been there probably 4 times.  Also they have Abuelita hot chocolate!  So great for a SF evening.   They have many vegetarian selections, and they're willing to top your meal with a fried egg or two if you just ask.

I can't praise this place enough.  Good job, guys.
author: Shannon W.

description: Soooooo good! I love these Tortas. I woke up this morning and thought quietly to myself I would really like a torta today and then a few hours later my fiancé said do you wanna go to La Torta Gorda? I took that as a sign. Wow these tortas are so filling and have such amazing flavor. The Chicken Tinga is my favorite I also love the Pierna Enchilada. I give this five stars because not only is there food amazing the people who work here could not be any nicer thank you La Torta Goda for making my tummy smile.
author: Jeni Z.

description:
This restaurant is an absolute treasure in the heart of the Mish.  Friendly, kind of a retro kooky diner look, exceptionally clean, and with a unique menu that you just have to explore.  I've ordered things where I didn't know what the heck the ingredients were but they were delicious!  Maybe I was eating cactus or eggplant or mushrooms.  It doesn't matter; it's all great!  Be prepared if you order a torta "regular" it will be HUGE (ideal for sharing).

It is so clear that the owners care a great deal about preparing and serving excellent fresh food and making sure that you are glad you stopped by.  

Like others, I had passed this place by countless times.  It was shocking when I opened the door, walked in and felt like....this is the place.

Went for Halloween/Dia de los Muertos time the last three years and they always have a beautiful altar set up in the front of the restaurant.

Great food, very reasonable prices, great vibe, great people.  
Go! 

ps: be sure to leave your generous tip in the tip jar at the front, next to the cash register.
author: Jan C.

description:
I'm a huge fan of solid portions of food.  Getting my money's worth is important to everyone unless you're on the upper echelon of "greenbacks in yo pocket." 
Here, the environment is warm and friendly, the tortas are big and very tasty, seasoned and cooked to perfection.  I've always thought it was too close to call whether a panini is better or torta, but I guess it's kinda different and kinda similar when you discuss the process of making the sandwich.  It's a nice lunch place and worth five or six dollars to put back into the community.  Also enjoy 24th street...
Please eat here soon!
author: felix c.

description: The pierna enchilada torta is this mexican pulled pork sandwich.  It has beans, avocado, some other stuff, and comes with this delicious hot sauce that tastes like bbq sauce.  I like the patio in the back but the food is just ok.
author: Matthew P.

description: Strongly recommend this to anyone that is a fan of tortas. I'm very picky when it comes to tortas but I love this place. They are giant portions and the bread is my favorite part. Please try for yourself and spread the word.
author: D A.

description:
The best torta in the City.
I tried the junior milanesa (beef) with chipotle.
It was the perfect size! Just the perfect amount.
The bread they use is fantastic, the torta is constructed perfectly.
No drips of grease here.
Don't forget to ask for the home made hot sauce. It has the perfect amount of heat, enough to break a sweat but not enough to need to drink 2 liters of water. It has a sweet after taste too.
Next time, Regular size?
author: Geordie E.

description: The Mexican sweet corn truffle enchilada thingy that looked more like a giant taco was DELICIOUS and really cheap! I was stuffed after one, but ate the second one as well because it was so tasty! Then I was REALLY stuffed! The service was friendly and quick and they take credit cards too...woo-hoo!
author: Susie D.

description:
I've tried a few torta places on 24th and this place is still my favorite.  Especially the vegetariano torta.  So, so good.  

Never had a torta?  Well, it's a delicious toasted sandwich with cheese, avocado, beans, jalapenos, tomatoes with a super tasty sauce to squeeze atop each bite. 

This place has really great old decor and a nice back patio.  

Try one.  They're cheap, filling and yumtastic.
author: Ames P.

description:
RUN! DO NOT WALK TO LA TORTA GORDA!! Fantastic Tortas & Poblanas Dishes!  Everyone who works here is super nice and helpful and the prices are really budget friendly.  
You MUST try the Pambazos Torta--chorizo, potatoes, lettuce,cheese & sour cream with a great red sauce!!  And the Carnitas Torta is close behind as my fave! 
They do breakfast, lunch and early dinner as well as great shakes, smoothies & agua frescas.  
I love this place!!
author: k k.

description: You really feel like you could be in another country when enjoying a delicious Torta here. I remember my first visit blew my mind but on my visit today the food wasn't as memorable. I'll definitely be back for another try. I really like this spot.
author: M L.

description: This place is awesome sauce! Cheap and delicious would be some of the correct adjectives to describe this place. This place is close to SFGH which is great because I can just walk here after I'm done with my volunteer shifts. I only order the pierna enchilada torta whenever I come here. Junior size. I pride myself on my ability to eat a lot, which translates to the junior size always fills me up. The torta is filled with a good amount of meat and is served with this mild sauce which makes the torta more tasty. All of this delicious awesomeness for five bucks?! This place is made of quality.
author: Lauren L.

description:
LTG is fantastic! Super friendly service, cute diner atmosphere and tasty tasty  food- breakfast, lunch and dinner.  

*takes credit cards
author: Jessi H.

description: good service, good people and hecka good tortas.  the traditional breakfasts are tasty as well :)
author: Will C.

description: By mistake, I called the wrong Torta store to order a torta to go. I got the Hawaiian torta and the ham was very fatty and cheap. I will never come here every again.
author: Helen L.

description:
Hands down the best tortas I've ever had.  My favorite is chorizo and egg with chipotle.  The bread is wonderful and different than most tortas I've had; must be made there or nearby, tasting very fresh.  Also great bananna liquados.  I especially love this place because it's rarely crowded.  You could wait 1/2 an hour+ for a seat at the St. Francis (which I do love), or, get an awesome torta in 5 mins.  They've got junior and large size tortas:  get a junior or split a large with someone, unless you're _really_ hungry.

Yelp says it's good for dinner and lunch.  Actually, it's great for breakfast too.  Closes early, like around 8PM.

As many others mention, the folks in there are super nice.

Anyhow, I signed up for yelp just to give this place a great review.  Don't pass it up.
author: Hawkeye P.

description: This place is heaven on earth! The tortas are freakin amazing. The guy that works the counter is always very nice. They make special concessions for my persnickety vegetarian tendency. "May I have a chile relleno torta, no red sauce, extra green sauce, extra jalapenos..." and so on. What's that you say? You'll deliver these delectable, cranium sized heart stoppers? I would marry this place if I could.
author: Emma G.

description: Very casual place, I walked in and ordered the pierna enchilada torta to go, they handed me my torta within five minutes and I was happily on my way. The torta itself was delicious!! Crispy bread, saucy, savory meat and pickled jalapenos, so simple, so delicious.
author: Cathy T.

description:
La Torta = La BOMB.......  I used to hit up this TORTA DELI right up the street.  It was a small family owned jewel that didn't have a name.  On my way there it seemed they  went out of business so I took my business to this place 

With a Torta craving on my mind  the GF and I headed to La Torta Gorda. I must say the Carne Asada Torta was DELICIOUS.  The soft grilled Torta bread topped with mexican cheese, re fried beans, onion and Jalapeno (no Mayo) for 6.95 is the best bargain for your buck.  FYI the sandwich is huge.  Perfect to share with a loved one

 With a number of Torta place on 24th street I recommend you check this place out
author: Robert M.

description:
OMG their torta's are bomb! This place hit the spot BIG time for me! I wouldn't come here for anything but their big, juicy, meaty, cheesy delicious sandwiches (tortas) - but they do them well it's worth the trip even though the rest of their items don't look too tempting for me. What seemed strange is their name has 'torta' in it right? So obviously these sandwiches are their main attraction. And while watching them work they only have 2 sandwich presses back there. And they're not like giant either. So we thought the wait would be a while since there was a big group of guys in front of us, but they have great space and time management on those grills and the wait was only about 8 minutes. Not too bad. They've got a cute patio in the back so we got to enjoy our yummy sandwiches in the sunshine which is always an added treat. We tried the Pierna enchilada torta (big eats list item) as well as a saucy carne asada torta. I thought the regular size was way too big so i got the junior. At first glance it was big enough but it tasted soooo good I really wanted more, not that i wasn't totally full after my slightly smaller sandwich, it was just the kind of good that you want to continue eating until you're to the painfully uncomfortably full you know? One more great reason to go, their hot sauce - add it to you torta for a special added kick. 
We'll definitely be back!
author: Audrey V.

description: Proof positive of 24th St's latin cred: not one, but *two* great tortas places.  Popularity-wise, LTG is sort of the Husker Du to TLP's R.E.M, which is really too bad.  The tortas here may not have TLP's over-the-top sauce-oozing messiness, but they're still monstrously large and delicious (I went with the Pierna, aka roast leg of pork).  And best of all, it's in an old converted diner that's uncannily reminiscent of St Francis Fountain a few doors down (must be another relic of 24th St's long-forgotten diner era?).  So it's got far better atmosphere than TLP, and you can even get breakfast.
author: Wes M.

description:
because when you combine all the flavors of the rainbow they form a delicious path that leads your stomach to a pot of gold...
viva la gorda!
author: Evan T.

description: Still in love with carne asada torta. I usually call ahead so I don't have to wait. When you're in the mood for something filling; a torta from here will hit the spot.
author: Michael S.

description:
I have eaten breakfast here many times but did not feel that my review would be justified until I tried La actual Torta Gorda. I elected to go with the Jr. Torta which was still plenty of food. Normally I have the veggie omelet, which is packed with about 10 different kinds of veggies. They also have 2 different (verde y rojo) delicious hot sauces that they make. It might help to speak spanish when ordering. The people who work there are super friendly and go out of their way to serve you in a quick and helpful manner. 
I find it sad that there is a line out the door at the St. Francis Fountain diner a few doors down every morning just because it's the 'cool' place to eat. St. F's is also good (in an overwhelming fattening way) but it just shows that most people aren't very willing to try something new, even if it means waiting for 1/2 an hour before being seated. I on the other hand love trying new things, and that is why I love everyone's suggestions here on yelp.
author: Paulette B.

description: San Francisco Mag suggested this place for their Pierna Enchilada Torta.  I am starting a summer sandwich tour and this was a good start for sandwich #1.  Perfect size, nice and crisp, the pulled pork had an amazing flavor and the jalapenos added a nice crisp crunch.  I suggest you use the smokey sauce on top to round the sandwich out and wash it down with a mexican coca-cola.   We did try the mega cubano as suggested by the owner.   That sandwich is ridix!
author: Bryan H.

description:
#39 On the "Big Eat SF" list  - pierna enchilada torta

so, to be honest, it took me a while to remember eating this. i knew i ate it because 2 friends an i did 10 items on this list in one day, with a carefully crafted game plan of driving and hitting up items that were clustered, with each person running off to various places to save time. and i clearly remember the other items around this...but this took awhile. so it was good, but not crazy memorable good...
author: S V.

description: La Torta Gorda was okay but not great.  We had brunch there today, and the huevos con chorizo were tasty but a little uninspired, as were the huevos divorciados.  I got a torta to go that was not at all thrilling; the carne asada one was a bunch of carne asada between bread and not much else (admittedly, I asked them to hold the refried beans).  On the plus side, there's a nice outside seating area in the back that was quite pleasant when the sun was out, and the service was friendly and attentive.  Not sure I would make a special effort to go back, but it was  okay.  I'd say 2.5 stars if Yelp would let me.
author: moosedog i.

description: We really enjoyed ourselves here on a Saturday afternoon.  We sat at the counter & were attended to quickly.  Shared a juice in a large goblet that was plenty for two.  My partner had the lamb special & I had the enchiladas.  The portions were generous & tasty.  The staff was super efficient & friendly.  We took some of our food home as we couldn't finish it all.  I'd definitely go back & sample more dishes.  Bottom line:  Food was good & plentiful.  The staff & environment were extremely friendly.  I will definitely go back & recommend this place to my friends.  It's friendly & not pretentious which fits perfectly for me.  This place was down to earth & fit the bill.  Thanks for a great dining experience!
author: Arex O.

description:
I'm upgrading my stars to 5. I've now been here 3 times in one month, and I just love it. I love their waitress -- I don't know her name yet. But she is such a warm, friendly, easy-to-laugh person.. she just makes the whole vibe in that restaurant warm and friendly.

My fave breakfast dishes so far: Huevos divorciados and Quesadillas (1 huitlacoche - indigenous rotten corn that's delicious! and 1 flor de calabaza).
author: Jo G.

description: Ok so I've read enough about tortas.  Has anyone tried their "Mole Poblanos Enchiladas" or "Flor de Calabaza Quesadillas"? And how about the "Tacos al Pastor" (oil free with little chunks of pineapple) I grew up in Mexico and let me tell you, this is the best place to have any one of the above.  This place is as good as it gets and everything I have eaten there tastes homemade.  Did I mention that the quesadilla tortilla is made out corn "masa" on the spot?  I haven't had a torta yet but I will probably try it next time.  The "aguas frescas" are delicious and I can really go on and on about how good this place is but I'll let you go and find out for yourself.  I almost forgot, the service is outstanding!!
author: Miriam M.

description: Allrightee then if you want a sandwich, between york and Hampshire on 24th street.... or a gorda..then this place is Mexican sandwich heaven:)  yummy is what I have to say and everyone I bring there is YET ANOTHER repeat customer....  Louis, the order taker, nice man, his car just got stolen, tip him good, because the food is so good, and sometimes you can get a coffee refill if you earn your way, stripes, I would say..I get great sandwiches with so many choices, and those gorda things every one loves but yet I only have had one once in a while.....Bella loves it there too, all year long they still have plenty of avocados....anyway, its the bomb, prove me wrong...
author: Tamara M.

description:
What the other reviews have overlooked is the profoundly unclassifiable nature of this restaurant. It has 3 personalities.

First, it's a taqueria. It's in the south mission, everyone who works there is latino, they specialize in tortas, they have shelves behind the register with abuelito hot chocolate and ramen, and when I was there the whole back of the restaurant was filled with a sprawling familia latina, having quite a good time.

Second, it's a 1950s soda shop. You go in and you can sit down at the bar on a row of soft red cushioned stools. There are big Coca-Cola light fixtures that hang down from the ceiling. While I waited for my meal a well-curved white woman and her daughter came in to order a chocolate milkshake. For all I know they drank it with 2 straws, cheek to cheek, while listening to Paul Anka.

Third, it's a french cafe. They have those faux french liquor art posters everywhere. I ordered a chorizo and egg torta. The guy calls out "chorizo y huevo..?" so I go to retrieve it, expecting a torta similar to what I might find up the street at Taco Loco or Farolito. Instead I get an impeccably crafted masterpiece, a work of art, not a drop of grease anywhere, just good mexican ingredients tightly wrapped in paper, looking just like a $15 panini sandwich. A french one.

Maybe the best fresh-squeezed grapefruit juice of my life, too.
author: Brent S.

description: Tuna Melt is great.  Tortas (except for their El Pastor meat...and I can't say anything about beef) are excellent.  They make it fresh.  They make their aguas frescas fresh.  It's good shite.  Go there for lunch and converse with the construction workers.  There are seats, but only outside, and only in the way of the order window.  This is the only reason I give it 4 stars.
author: Ben H.

description: They just moved further on 24th street and they seriously deserved it. All the best for them. The new location has some delightfully kitsch 50ness that makes it really cute. Their tortas are still GORDAs and they are absoultely filling and fresh. The liquado de fresa had something like a chemical background though...hmmmm.  Don't take the three stars like something bad...it's just that I like tortas better in another place.
author: Dario B.

description: Best Tortas in the city, period. I've been going there since they were a hole in the wall.
author: Anders F.

description: Started my quest for the perfect torta last weekend. Decided to try this place first having passed by it many times and seeing some good reviews on here. Walked in and grabbed a seat at the counter. I asked the guys working there if I should get carnitas or pastor. Pastor was recommended so I ordered one with everything on it.  Went for the large size since it was only like $2 more. It turned out to be a huge sandwich. It was tastey, although not the best pastor I've had.
author: Brian J.

description: Their tortas aren't have bad, pollo milanesa is slightly dry but they have other options for food that look pretty good. I've just always gotten the pollo milanesa because it comes with queso fresco and avocados. The bread is nice and soft and it goes great with the rest of the insides of the sandwich!
author: Gina R.

description: This is my first time eating at La Torta Gorda and sadly, I will probably not return.  I ordered the Milanesa sandwich and when I got it, it tasted really bland and it was riddled with jalepenos.  Well, I don't like or eat jalepenos and I wished they had asked me if i wanted it. (spicy food is NOT for everyone, you know).  And when I ordered the horchata, it was way too sweet.  So for my nearly $10 lunch, I think I rather spend it somewhere else.
author: N A.

description: There's a reason why Puebla, Mexico is know for its food, and this restaurant is a good reminder of that. It's a great place for breakfast or lunch in the Mission (I've never had dinner here; that might be good too). The food is fresh and portions are good-sized but not so huge and overloaded with cheese that you have to unbutton your jeans after a meal. I love the huevos rancheros and my boyfriend loves the quesadillas de huitlacoche. They don't always have pozole, but when they do, it's excellent. It amazes me that there's always a huge line at the restaurant on the corner, a few doors down, when this place is so good. Check it out!
author: Andrea B.

description: Dined here for the 1st time 9/11/10.  Had high hopes only to have them get smaller as time wore on.  Wait person acknowledged I was going to be dining on the back patio.  15 minutes passed and no wait person or menu.  So I went inside, she apologized profusely.  I ordered the pulled pork 1/2 size Torta which was very good by the way.  But to my dismay there was no Pineapple as the menu said & I didn't realize this till 1/2 way through.  Other disconcerting feature, all the "extra items mentioned" I thought would be "on the side" and low and behold they were "inside" the sandwich.  So from a presentation perspective to receive a sandwich all wrapped up in wax paper, in a basket w/nothing else was somewhat boring.  I did ask for some chips which they don't usually provide but server was very accommodating.  All this being said, waiting 25 minutes for just a sandwich seemed a bit much.  Watermelon drink and sandwich totaled $10.00 (kind of steep for so little).  I felt all the owners/cooks & wait people were self absorbed in some sport game on the TV and therefore other patrons were being ignored.  Will I go back, yes, one more time to try something else.  If i find the serve is yet again "spotty" at best, I won't be returning.  Sorry to write such a bummer of a review when all other reviews were glowing, but obviously my experience was much different than anyone else's.
author: Marla B.

description: my girlfriend brought me here a month ago and i was skeptical. i'm more of a burrito guy, even a quesadilla or nachos get my vote before tortas. but i'm always willing to try new things. and i'm glad i did....i got a cubana torta and good lord this thing was epic. it comes packed with FOUR kind of meat...ham, turkey, carnitas-esque pork and hot dog. yes, hot dog. at that moment in time while i was eating my sandwich my whole mind, body and existence were centered around this most legendary of legendary foods. if there was a culinary embodiment of the term "wins" it was this torta. oh and their horchata is the best i've ever had. they make it fresh on the spot in the blender, it's not sitting in some container all day, so it's real rich and frothy. pure excellence.
author: Dan C.

description: Tortas are good but they need a little more flavor and not as big as they claim. Still would prefer going to LOS PICUDOS for tortas. Their tortas are bigger, cheaper and more flavorful.
author: Maria H.

description: Best tortas in the City. Jamon con Huevo sin Queso is the best. Not the best service (if you come in during the lunch hour) takes them a while, and with good reason, lots and lots of people call in big orders. Great prices. I always leave happy with a full belly.
author: Arnold S.

description:
this review is based on a very limited sampling of the menu.

their horchata is made to order and hands down the best one i've ever had, anywhere. i didn't know horchata's could be this good.

unfortunately, they're breakfast doesn't match it. they can't cook eggs either. why is this such a challenge for so many short order cooks?  check out usulutan on harrison and 24th for a good breakfast, but get your horchata here first.

the fellow behind the counter is always friendly, and the venue is nice too. maybe i'll explore the menu further than breakfast one day.
author: Combi C.

description: holy crap! i have been living blocks away from them for the last year, el metate is less than a block away so it always satisfied my mexican food cravings, but then! my new roommate who works on 24th discovered LA TORTA GORDA!!! bomb.com. seriously. the best local sandwich/torta joint ever. my roomie ordered a couple watermelon agua frescas and the lady made them from scratch with smartwater. cooome on, that's amazing. bomb.
